Amber/copper color ; medium-sized , off-white head. Caramel malt and grass in the intensive aroma. Perfect balance of malt and Chech hops in taste. Easy to drink , but it is not just a regular thirst-quencher , it is something to enjoy .
Bottle and draft. Amber Vienna color. Very sessionable with lots of flavor. Very good for a flagship beer

my first rating. Aroma, pretty good, smells like a good lager. Apperance, couldnt tell drank it straight out the bottle. Taste, not really bitter or sour, a little bit sweet. Palate, oily texture, a little fizzy, long finsh. Overall, not a bad lager.

"Man, that freaky ass clown label sure gets your attention. A brew Ive passed on several times but decided to give a few Coneys a whirl. This ones just ok... Light grassy hops and some grainy malt and a bit of sweetness, with a slightly bitter finish. Average brew."
caramel, bread, hay, roasty , nuts, resin, citrus, dough, alcohol, orange, hazy, white foam, lacy, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish,

This was poured into a pilsener glass.
The appearance has a nice bronzed amber color with a light transparency about it to have some light carbonation to be seen rising. There is a two finger white foamy head that mushroom caps and dissipates at a nice pace leaving a messy sort of thick lacing all around the glass.
The smell had some dried sweet caramel malts with a rich sort of nuttiness running underneath to amplify a wonderful aroma.
The taste was extremely nice through the rich caramel malts and a delicate nutty flavoring.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a pretty good sessionability about it. The carbonation ends up being somewhat smooth and creamy but still lets in enough harshness.
Overall, whoah, where did this come from Schmaltz? Good job with making a very good Vienna Lager.

Probably the first good lager I ever had. With actual taste, it left me quite surprised. With hints of caramel and bitterness, but all at a subdued lager level. I found it to be very spicy and herby as well, but all within a comfortable range. I rated it so high, because this is what lagers have the potential to be, instead of light piss water.

Poured into an imperial pint glass. This lager poured a great amber cloudy color with a frothy head. What a great flavor! This is a bold lager, lager being the foundation. On top of that just enough malt and a good heap of hops. Big round mouthy flavor. Cheers!

On tap @ Brass Monkey, NY. Clear amber color with thin creamy off-white head, excellent lacing and average sparkling appearance. Aroma of toasted, caramel and biscuit malt, herbal and mild floral hops. Taste starts with sweet caramel malt, following is refreshing fruity and grainy sour, while finish is moderate bitter. Medium body, slick texture and average carbonation in palate. Surprisingly good for bottom fermentation brew, but thats American quality...
4/9/2011. From bottle. Light amber color with a white head. Malty aromas with hops. Good balance, plenty of hops and flavors. Very tasty.
Tasty lager here. Bubbly and with caramel notes. Ambet looking, light bodied. Short, weak palate, and thats why is just a good try but nothing compare to the Brooklyn Lager.

Bottle. Pours slightly hazy amber with small off-white head. Clear aroma of grain with touches molasses and caramel. Bitter, hoppy flavour with notes of caramel and citrus. Not bad, but more reminiscent of an APA than an Aber Lager.

Bold, orange-amber in color with a full, off-white colored head, this beer is clean with moderate carbonation. The aroma is simply of an amber lager, with light caramel easily dominating the nose. A grainy character is also present, coupling with a dusty antique smell. The flavor is as expected, but very close in redness to that of an amber ale. Caramel malts prevail slightly over the inherent overall lager character. Something earthy
remains at its core, though, and shines in the finish. Its likely pilsener malts and perhaps the character of its hops, but it simply tastes like the caramel simply, and finally, takes the back seat. Overall, not that I pleasant, but still much better than most amber lagers.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a lager glass. 

Appearance: Dark copper to brown proper. Mostly hazy but some transparency to it. Forms a small, off white soapy head which doesnt last very long or lace much.

Smell: Plenty of malts for a lager. Very similar to a marzen with hints of confectionary sweetness, but a noticeable lager aroma overall.

Taste: Its rare that you can smell malts in a lager (aside from a doppelbock), so you can imagine how much that will come through in the taste. And indeed Coney Island Lager is quite malty. The bottle indicates it uses 8 different malts and 6 types of hops. They certainly work well together, creating for a slightly toasty, biscuity malt taste with accompanying bitterness. A light caramel flavor is present as well, mostly on the finish, and provides a good balance to the standard "beer" taste found here. 

Drinkability: You could mistake Coney Island Lager for an ale due to the taste, but the actual drinkability is classic lager style. The fizziness makes the mouthfeel quite lively all the way through with a slight carbonation burn if drank too fast. The mouthfeel is thick than your average lager in conjunction with a perfectly medium bodied palate, but mostly clean in the aftertaste (although I would not describe this beer as being refreshing). The 5.5% ABV weight seems to fit that frame perfectly: more "pep" than your average lager, but nothing even approaching the stronger or imperial territories.

Crackly pale ale malts, cereal grains, and a spicy/herbal hop character in the aroma; a touch coarse. Medium body; medium-high carbonation; following the nose, the approach is rough here: excess CO2, sharp bitterness and (seemingly) some tannic qualities from the malt; the flavors endearing once one gets past that, showing some really nice cereal grains, spicy hop flavor, and toasty Pils malt; plenty tasty going on here, but a muddled and sharp mouthfeel isnt helping. Lasting toasty finish: modest dryness, lingering mineral bitterness and cereal grains.

Bottle pours amber with a creamy white head.  Aroma shows notes of toffee, grass and light citrus.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of peach and some additional earthy/herbal hops.
At a tasting, thanks DSG, bottle, reddish, hoppy and fruity aroma, dry, bitter aftertaste, and overall a very rich and interesting beer.

Pint draft at Lemon Tree, Downers Grove. Nice smell, hint of fresh yeast over a light malt nose.Cloudy amber body with just a few bubbles feeding into a lacy, creamy head. Taste is very full. Richly malted with toasty, nearly caramel Vienna malt, crisp with just the right choice of mostly noble hops. Some unfiltered yeast comes out halfway through, and a deeper caramel note toward the end.

Tap at a city sports bar. Pours a hazy bronze with a slightly creamy white head. Aroma is a mix of raisin and resin with some caramel in the background. Slightly bready flavor with toasted malt and some diacetyl notes. The flavor is overall tame, somewhat watered down. Soft and cream mouthfeel. Enjoyable overall, but the flavors are more "distant" than perhaps they should be.

2/5/11.  Bomber.  Clear red pour with a foamy tan head that cuts in half but lasts.  Grainy metallic grainy aroma with a spicy hop bite.  Dry grainy flavor with a hint of chocolate, caramel, and malt.  A bit papery as well.  Meh.

Translucent coper, thin beige head, clingy medium-full body, medium carbonation.

Aroma: sweet amber malt, floral hops with a hint of citrus, and notes of bread and minerality.

Taste: leafy hops, lots of toffee malt, and a touch of grainy minerality. Gets a bit cloying and worty by second half.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  The beer pours a medium to slightly dark golden color, with a moderate white head.  Germanic character malt immediately makes itself apparent in the nose, showing a character all too rare in American-made lagers.  These characters move through the palate, giving the beer a malty and pleasing profile that reflects what lagers can be, when made well.  Hops provide some balance, but dont seem to reflect the labels advertisement of their prodigious use.  Carbonation is nicely dialed in.  The finish is malty without becoming tiresome, and lingers on the palate.  Overall, enjoyable and quaffable.

Pours a cloudy amber with orange hues.  Aroma of dough, toasted grain and nuts.  Flavor is roasted grain with a slight sourness and a pine hops in the finish.  Not too bad.  Has somewhat of a Marzen flavor, but with more hops and toned down malt.

Rich amber/cider color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of floral hops, citrus, & malt; Flavor of slight roasted sweet malt, caramel, hops, and some nuts; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Pretty good overall.

Pours a clear amber with a medium sized head and rather nice lacing.  Nose has floral and bread notes.  Flavor is moderately bitter and hop biased with notes of wood and spice.  Slightly citrus bitter finish.

It pours a light amber color with a tiny ring of head and a small amount of carbonation and lacing.

This has a huge amount of toasted malt,light carmel,little grains.

The flavor is sweet malt,grains,some bready notes and a good does of hops.

It finishes with a a dryness and a little sweetness from a carmel. Not really your traditional lager.. Not a bad beer but not worth the price tag.

Quite a delicious hoppy and malty lager! Looks like a Sam Adams (Boston Lager), but this one has much more roasty malty sweetness than a B.L. Good hoppy bite to keep all you hopheads happy. Clean lightly sweet finish. Probably hoppier than most Viennas Ive had, but quite interesting and drinkable.

Cool Coney Island / Luna Park crazy face on the label.  Pretty dark pour for a lager.  Nice aroma for the style too - malty with floral tones.  This is a pretty dry, full-flavored lager with a lightly smokey finish.  An excellent lager!  Schmaltz makes some of the best lagers available.  I cant think of a better one offhand.
Draught at Fette Sau. Hazy red brown colour. Mild and very round caramel malt flavour. Low to medium bitterness. Very clean.

Fresh malty aroma, nice light copper color and an off-white head.   Almost fizzy carbonation keeps big bubbles flowing in this very malt driven brew.   Not a light lager by any means, this has a good malty flavor that reminds me of fresh amber ale homebrew, but with the lightness and crisp hop flavor of a lager.  Light caramel sweetness along with dryness in the finish.   Definitely defies traditional categories.
Reddish lager nice hop flavor. some malty sweetness. some sips watery. unusual after taste. Serving: bottle
At a tasting: some caramel malt, some herbal notes, some grainy notes, some hoppy bitterness, some matalic notes, dry finish, decent lager,

Bottle sample at a tasting. Huge thanks Ambar for bringing me this bottle from the States! Clear amber. Aroma of toasted malt, a bit of caramel hints, graininess and hoppy hints. Sweet toasty flavor, a bit grainy, with bread notes and a bitter, hoppy finish with a bit of pine needles. Medium-bodied.
bottle.  sweet grains, light oat and fruity bread note.  not too bad.   not the best session beer as the sweet cornbread malts grow tiring eventually.

at a tasting, thanks DSG, clear orange colour with some pinkish streaks, malty aroma with honey and marmalade,flavours of peach, mango and passion fruit, and a strong but mellow bitterness, bitter sour aftertaste. Good but a little too hoppy.
At a tasting, thanks DSG, pours an amazing orange with a medium head, aroma of pineapple, peach, pine and wood, dry flavor with grapefruit, pineapple and bitter finish, medium body, nice.

Bomber. Big malty aroma of caramel, molasses and dry wood. Flavor is the same with more of the earthy malt on the front, joined by some lightly bitter pecan and light cocoa, and then just enough light citrus and woody hop to dry the finish. Deep copper with a long lasting film of creamy bubbles. Medium bodied, sweet, and smooth.
Clear amber color with a thick rocky head. Aroma is bready and herbal, with a hint of fruit. Flavor is moderately bitter. Crisp finish. A good beer.
Tasting - Gulf Brew 2010 - normally Id have better notes, but the only thing my notes say on this beer is that Id buy it.  I must have enjoyed the look of this pour.  I never give anything a 5.
Pours a dark amber color.  Has a medium sized off white head.  Smells of malts with a little bit of hops mixed in.  Taste is similar.  Pretty refreshing beer.

$5 220z bomb - My first try Shmaltz Brewing.  I was feeling adventurous and gambled on this moderately priced lager (usually would not spend decent money on an individual bottle of lager).  You know what, not bad.  Refreshing and surprisingly complex flavors.  Reminds me of some of the German-style lagers out there.  Good summer choice and I might even consider a re-buy in the future.

Big bottle and a small bottle. Dark copper tinted amber with almost a finger of white-ish foam. They pack a lot of ingredients into some of these beers. Kind of a cedary woody malt scent. Lots of spice, caramel, nut, wood and biscuit with a lasting hop aftertaste. Pretty solid.
12 oz. bottle.  Pours a medium amber with a nice off-white head that lasts.  Aroma of caramel and a bit of hops.  Taste is fruity, sweet caramel and hops.  Nice blend.  Very drinkable lager.

Bottle. Pours a clear copper color with a decent head. Strong malt presence with some yeast as well. Light caramel notes. Malty taste with a caramel presence. Some toffee as well. Interesting mesh. More of an Amber Ale, but still pretty tasty.

Shmaltz Brewing Company--Coney Island Lagers--Coney Island Lager--2008 22 oz. Bottle.  5.50% ABV.  30 IBUs?  (3.75 / 5.0)  Pale Lager.  Rich creamy lacy off white head.  Clear rich amber gold color.  Sediment hint.  Malty mild hop front.  Mellow sweet mildly creamy malty smooth rich caramel body.  Cloying malt mild hop spice end.  8 Malts 6 Hops Typical Complicated Formulation detracts from flavor.  Sampled 9/13/2009.  2 @ $4.99 Each.
(bottle) deep amber with off white head. Aroma of malt and spicy hops. Flavor was largely caramel malt with floral hops in the finish.

Pours a dark amber color that is a little hazy with an off white head.The aroma is a floral orange sent.The taste is a hopy citrus with a slight malt sweetness.The body is medium and the finish is a bitter aftertaste that grows as you drink.Overall a good beer.
On tap at sweet grass grill.  Pour is a normal amber with small head.  taste is slightly sweet with some malt, nothing overpowering or stanout about this inoffensive lager.
On cask at Spuyten Duyvil. Same hop as Nogne IPA and Imp Brown actually. Onion. A bit watery. Light hop bitterness, but quite a bit of hop flavor. More nuttyness. More soap. Nice bread in the finish.
A dark copper pour with off-white head.  It has a bready malt aroma with a hint of caramel.  The taste is mildly sweet to start with a full body, lively carbonation, and moderately bitter finish.
Bottle pours a clear amber body with large pillowy off-white head, nice lacing. Scent is sweet orange/floral. Flavor is a bit spicy but it feels like water.
Had on tap in a dark bar on a sunny day. Good tasting, but not worth repeating.
UPDATED: APR 29, 2010 Robust lager. Amber color with white head. Sweet mildly hoppy nose. Taste is grainy cereal with some citrus, caramel and floral herbs. Rated 9/20/08

Brown w/ a decent head of mixed bubbles and splotchy lacing. Nose is caramel and butterscotch. Once tasted, the butterscotch takes on that more chemically diacetyl flavor and competes w/ some Munich-like malts and a bit of raisin fruitiness. Medium bodied and bit slick and oily w/ slightly too much carbonation. Finishes w/ an earthy bitterness. The further I dig into this beer, the less I like it. Just a bad show all around.

On tap for growler fills at Half Time.  Pours a mostly clear light brown with a thin beige head.  Sweet caramel, grains, plastic.  Earthy and malty with a bitter hop presence, but very boring.  Finishes with some bitterness and grain.  Inoffensive but very dull.

I was pleasantly surprised by this beer, 22oz bottle from the local Crowns. Barely noticeable sweet/hoppy aroma, pours smooth with a decent white head. Hazel/orange color. Tastes of floral hops and a noticeable caramel taste which is very pleasant. Easy to drink, overall an awesome beer.
tap at some random NYC bar. honey orange pour. nice caramel malts, grassy and toffee-like candy. Astringency is annoying me on this one, though. eh.

Had this on tap at Carnival Bar in NYC.  Pours a translucent mild brown color with a thin white head.  The taste is one of multiple flavors.  fruit and bread dominate at first, and then give way to just a slight edge at the end.  Highly enjoyable.

Bottle. Aroma is caramel sweet with resiny/piney hop notes and subdued grain character. Clear amber, good color for style. Mostly fruity/caramel sweet flavor with light hop presence. Too sweet in the middle but finishes dry. A bit muddled, and not a great interpretation of the style in my opinion. Nonetheless, fairly drinkable.
From an old rating note - bomber.  Nice lager.  Light caramel aroma.  Smooth.  Well-balanced.  Slight nuttiness with some dark fruits.  All Ive got other than a score.

A surprising lager!  Poured amber with white head on draft at St Paul Summer Beer Fest, nose was caramel and a bit of hops.  The taste up front was a bit of hops that lead into a bready/yeasty malt with some caramel sweetness that finishes rather bitter.  A lager I like to drink, not bad at all!

22 oz bomber given to me from rebelbeerguy(a.k.a. Tim) on Christmas. Poured a clear orange amber with lots of large clinging bubbles and a smaller frothy off white head. Aroma started off a little sweet with lots of caramel malts and slight fruitiness followed up by dull grains and dough notes. Medium bodied with average carbonation and a very slight touch of hops bitterness on the end. Flavor is mostly grains and cereal with a slight touch of fruitiness near the end but that is replaced with an aftertaste of caramel malts. I was actually very pleasently suprised by this one and was expecting something close to a macro and wound up with a half way decent micro.
Draught at Ginger Man, NYCCopper color. Nice creamy aroma, with light toffee. Medium body strength, dry mouthfeel, malt flavor, strong bitterness, a touch of raw cereals. Not bad.
Bottle. Pours a dark golden color with asmall off-white head. Has a fruity malty grainy caramel aroma. Fruity malty grainy caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

pours out a dark clear honey with a tall off white head that was nicely lumpy.  the body is a clear light amber with very few bubbles in the mix.  the aromas are a slight malt backbone with nice overtones of a subtle yeast with a light hop presence making an apearance also.  it is a sweet yet bitter malty medium bodied flavor that is a little unbalanced.  has a nice hoppy taste in the back of the palate when it finishes, but malty with notes of hay, biscuits, butter and sweet nuts.  interesting mix of malt and very nice.the aftertaste is light and pleseant that is a little buttery on the tongue.  nice beer.

Tap @ The HeBrew Bash at the Blind Tiger NYC.  I was fricking wasted by the end so some of these rates might be a bit odd.  I have notes suggesting I found it very sweet on the nose with flavours of sweet white toast.

Bottle from Total Wine. Pours an amber color and a centimeter of white head. Aroma of piney hops and grains. Flavors include subtle caramel, wheat bread, toffee, nice hop bite in the finish. Lively carbonation and medium body. Nothing special, but a refreshing brew nonetheless.
Poured from big bottle.  Grassy and gassy aroma.  A bit darker than most lagers.  Very nice roasted malt flavor.  Crisp and clean feel.  Great finish.  A fine lager.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Bottled.  Almost clear amber. Perfumy grapefruit aroma. Sweet with clean crystaml malt. Some caramel and hay. Light-medium bodied with perfumy grapefruity hops building up to a mid-bitter finish. Shallow, but pleasant.
Very interesting beer.  Tastes like a mixture between a lager and an amber.  Darker in color than most lagers.  The full body mixed with amber taste makes for a nice experience on your palate.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a medium sized head of foamy finely sized off-white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a hazy softly carbonated orange brown colored body. The aroma was malty. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The thick flavor contained notes of dark malt. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

(bottle). Light cloudy amber color. Small off white hed which is mostly diminishing. Light malt and alcohol aromas. Sweet malt flavor. Avg duration. Smooth finish with lasting sweetness. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.
Shmaltz coney Island Lager on Tap at Ratte N Hum NYC.  Poured rich orange with a tan head.  Nose was sweet, rich and inviting.  Taste is sweet, hopped up and quite good, this is a quite nice Vienna.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a short lived white head, over a clear light amber (SRM 14) body.....nose is  rich with malts, toffee, cereal.....taste is very malt forward, with toasted cereal dominating early, later a light hop bitterness comes in to balance....mouth feel is medium, carbonation low to medium. This meets the Vienna style very well,
Sampled at the 8th Annual Music City Brewers Festival.  Dark red-orange, off white head.  Aroma is caramel, toasted malt.  Taste is toasted, grainy malt, caramel, light cocoa.
Draught.  Poured red with medium head, Grassy and malty aroma.  Sweet, but not too sweet malt tast, with a lekker hop finish.  Great on a hot day.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: On tap at the Bocktown, really nice place. Creamy white head with a fairly fruity smell. Pale yellow like a ubiquitous american lager. Somewhat bitter lager sensations. Really has some ropey or leather sensation in there. Much lager personality. Stronger than many lagers. Medium bitter medicinal finish.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours a nice copper brown color with small amount of foamy offwhite head.  Aroma is very very sweet with slight citric tones.  Flavor very very sweet and carmely (too much for my liking) and a bit of biscut to it.  Overall, not personally a fan, but I know my dad really liked it.  If youre into sweet beers this one is up your alley.

Citrus hops blend nicely with rich toasty, bready, biscuity malt character in the nose along with a touch of cabbage.  Hazy deep amber coloured body is topped by a decent, fizzy, tan head that recedes rapidly to a lasting cover.  Fairly sweet up front with some citrus and floral hops and moderate, offsetting bitterness.  Sweetness lingers in the aftertaste.  Medium light body feels a bit thin and carbonation is underwhelming,  Tulip glass.  Cellar temperature.  Bottle purchased at Brewery Creek in Jul-09.

This was my 2nd favorite beer from the Coney Island line-up of beers we had.  While it didnt knock my off my feet, it was solid enough to enjoy the entire pint without dumping it out like the other 2.  

The beer pours out a clear copper color with a small, tight white head.  Aroma has some light toasted malt notes, a bit biscuity, light floral notes and a touch of toffee.  Had they all been kicked up a few notches, it obviously would have been a much more interesting beer.  Flavor is sweet, with honeyish malt profile, toasted bread with a mild grassy hop character.  Easy to drink, easy to forget though.

Too foamy out of the bottle. A little sour skunk in the aroma but not off putting. Real nice color. Tastes like a honey lager with a little bitter kick at the end. thin body. Starts out weak but finishes strong.
Amber with a thin white head. Aroma is malt,citrus and hops. Flavor was malt,caramel and a bit of a bitter finish.
I liked this lager, one of the few I remember at beerfest.  Probably from the great label

clear dark amber, minor off white head that quickly reduces to bubbles, not much lace.  i notice big wet bubbles bursting from the bottleneck after the pour.  nose of sweet malt, touch of hops and caramel.  flavor is sweet malt, nicely balanced with  a citric hop bitterness and some caramel notes.  medium bodied, light bitter finish.  much more tasty than the bland label suggests.  single bottle purchased at binnys beverage depot in orland park.

Pours clear copper with nice frothy head and lively carbonation. Aroma is surprisingly hoppy; grapefruit and grassy resin with some caramel sweetness in the malt. Flavor has a nice balance of sweet, toffee like malt with an intermediate hop kick. Caramel and grassy hops poke through as well. Palate is disappointingly thin, finishing with the clean resinous quality of an ipa. Some aspects of this beer are better than average while others are lacking, but I must say it was an enjoyable quaff.

I know nothing about this brewery, but I must say I wasnt let down. Very cool bottle art but even better beer. Light, spicy, refreshing. It takes a lot for a lager to impress me and this sure did the job.

22oz. bottle.  Hoppy, spicy, toasty, malt aroma, mildly sweet and fruity with notes of cedar, caramel, dried herbs and slight pepper.  Clear light-medium amber color with a lasting, uneven off-white head and rings of lace.  Flavor is malty, toasty and biscuity to start, becoming sweeter, citric and hoppier as it goes, culminating in a semi-dry, moderately bitter and earthy finish.  Active and clean mouthfeel, body is medium.  Not really what I was expecting, I suppose, but I wasnt unpleasantly surprised.

22 oz bottle, via EDA.  Pours a clear copper body with a rather large foamy off-white head that retained fairly long due to the fizzy carbonation.  The nose is slightly grainy and dry toasty malt with some caramel and a touch of floral hops.  The flavor is slightly sweet with some toasty malt and huskiness.  Some bright hoppiness on the back end makes for a fairly crisp finish.  Doesnt really make me think Vienna too much, but its pretty drinkable.  Light to medium bodied with fizzy prickly carbonation.

On tap at Parkside Lounge, NYC.  Poured amber with thin head. Aroma was of malt.   Flavor mostly malt, palate was a bit fuller than average but I think with proper carbonation it may have felt creamier.
Bottle.  Pours an amber body with a white head.  Big malty caramel body with some earthy bitterness.  Hints of grass and spicy hoppiness.  Lightly beady with a hint of caramel.

(bottle - 22 oz) Clear amber color with a thin white head. Aroma is a decent amount of citrus, hops, and a light touch of malt at the end. Flavor begins with a lightly nutty taste that goes to a smooth malt middle. Some bitterness comes through at the end and leaves a slightly cloying and bitter taste on the palate. All in all, not that bad.
Bottle. Amber colour with a good creamy head. Citrus hops, especially orange. Citrus meets toffee flavours, some hints of metal. Thirst-quenching.
Bottle at the Rake, 7th March 2009. Clear rich amber. Good but a bit one dimensional.
22oz - Nice strong malt and bitter hops.  Plenty of carbonation.  The right beer at the right time for me.
A pretty well crafted brew. Was able to get in the SF Bay Area, which was kind of a surprise. Pours nice brown with a frothy head. Well worth a try. Goes down very smooth.

amber, light brown, minimal head.  nose is mellow... hoppy, pilsner yeast notes.  taste is crisp... well balanced hops and light/medium malts.  refreshing, dry finish.. made me realize how long its been since ive had a lager, and for a lager this is pretty nice.

Tap at the rake and bottle from utobeer at home with ang. The tap is infinitly superiour. Alround rating: Caramlt balanced with citrusy fresh american hop, id have thought it an american pale ale by style. Alround excellent very drinkable stuff.

22oz bottle. Pours clear orange brown, with a big tan head. Aroma of caramel, fruit, orange zest, and mild hops. Flavor is caramel, vanilla, and floral hops. Long finish, with earthy hops. Nice lager; flavorful and drinkable.

Bottle courtesy of Dave, the Magic one. Amber with a thin off white head. Sweet malt base, slightly soapy and floral hops with caramel, a hint of tea and a faint bitterness in the finish. Guess I like these Viennas as Brooklyn Lager aint bad either. This bottle was apparently not a patch on the draught version, which I whole heatedly believe but the only sample Ive had none the less. P.S. love the label!

Pours crisp darkish amber with a tall yellowish tan head that has great retention. Aroma is fruity, planty, and metalic, some floral and citrus hops. Flavor is fruity with slightly metallic notes, a little very light caramel and toast, a white chocolate. Finish is sweet straw, lightly bitter hops and some more light fruitiness. Not bad.

On tap at The Rake.  Chestnut colour, thin white head.  Not much of a lager.  Hoppy and some lager malt.  Pale ale style really.  Some peachy fruit.  Nice enough, bit of lager in it, but clearly hoppy.  Bit metallic.  And if it had been called an APA I would have given it higher.
One of the best beers i have ever tASTED. the aroma was superb and the taste lasted on your palet i give it a thumbs up
Decent brew. Pours amber with a whiteish head. Lots of malt and hops complexity. Freaky clown label. Drinkable, but I am not sure I would buy more...
Bottle.  Another day another bland lager.  Golden pour, white head.  Very malty nose with some hop notes.  Flavor is bland and boring.  NOTHING to distinguish itself from any other lager.

A Mes rate. Tap at the Rake. Clean dark golden with a thin white head. Looks like a pale ale rather than a lager. Lovely pale malt snout. One dimensional but still nice. Fruity flavour with some polite nods in a lagerly direction but this is much more of a pale ale. Good citric hints in the finish. Nice stuff.

Hoppy Vienna lager from the same mold as Brooklyn Lager.  Amber color with an off-white head.  Piney and floral.  Crisp and lagery on the mouthfeel.  Makes you want to eat 60 Nathans hot dogs in one sitting.
Draft at Redlight Redlight.  Fruity orange and lemon aromas mixed with some biscuit.  The floral hops lead to a bitter orange peel flavor.  A solid light, and citrusy, lager.

Draft at Redlight Redlight.  Dark amber in color, the body is crowned with a small, fluffy, off white head.  Random spotting marks the glass.  Aromas include lightly toasted caramel malts, glazed cereal grains, and balancing floral, peppery hops.  Flavors follow suit, simple yet well executed.  Peppery hops lend significant bitterness to the toasted, biscuity malts, floral notes and creamy pilsner yeast also helping out.  Moderate in body and carbonation, the body is entirely sessionable.  This brew is not bad at all, and certainly one of the best in its class.
Bottle.  Poured amber.  Aroma of malt, caramel.  Taste is of caramel, malt, grain.  Mouth is medium bodied.  Finish is smooth and a little sweet.  Overall, a simple drinkable beer.

Astringent. Buttery. Metallic. And thats just the nose. The appearance was the only thing this beer had going for it. 2 sips and I was done. Buttery, metallic, weird esters and just plain undrinkable. Bad bottle or batch, I assume. A real shame, as these guys typically make some good beer.
some nice aromas .. from light pine to apple .. an ok brew .. but lacks any complexity ..strange flavours, worse as it warms ..a decent lager but nothing at all special..the label will get ya...
Bottle. Pours amber orange with a fizzy white head. Sweet malt aroma with fruity esters and caramel. The flavor is sweet malt with some hoppy notes. Nicely balanced. Decent.

On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Pours a carmel colored amber. Malt loaded aroma, caramel, toasty, nutty. Taste is sweet malts, light honey. caramel. creamy mouthfeel. Sense some ringwood yeast (Middle Ages, Magic Hat) butteryness. Decent lager

On tap in Portland (Burnside and 12th NE - don’t know the name of the place).  A fine beer if you are tired, pissed and thirsty because Higgins closed earlier than they said they would.  Like a nice mellow pale with a bit of extra sweetness.

22oz. Bottle: Astringent aroma with notes of malts, grains, hops, light caramel, light toasting, slight sweetness, slight berry (juniper?), and herbs.  Poured orange/amber in color with a large, fluffy but dense off-white head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Very sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout, as well as a few large particles.  Small lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of hops, malts, slight cola, slight metal, light toasting, light caramel, slight medicine, herbs, hop leaves, grains, toffee, slight citrus, and some wheat.  Light to medium body.  Thin, chalky texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Lightly sweet, grainy, malt, and bitter hop finish is chalky.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2013 On tap at the Federal, Durham. Shared by my buddy David - thanks, David! Nice soft amber body, with a moderate beige head, minimal lacing. Sweet bready aroma with just a hint of fruits. The taste is very crisp and moderately nutty. Interesting how distinct the taste is from the aroma. Anyways, I found it an enjoyable, sessionable brew.
copper pour whitish nice head.  Aroma of spice, yeast and allium.  Bland taste and mimnimal body.  Better than most of it’s type, but not so good overall.

20081020  Bomber from Spirits RB.  Pale motor oil amber below a hefty beige sponge of quickly fading foam.  Aroma is mineral, salty, light peppery herbs.  Body is light with fairly aggressive eff.  Fair but lingering sweetness at odds with but beating a final bite of earthy hops.  Good enough.

Bottle from a NYC deli.
It’s the He’brew guys again, eh? I would have thought it risky to cahrge serious money for lager in such a fierce market.
But this is a nice, malty, pleasant lager, probably similar to what you could have had on Coney Island ca 1910. That being said, all the fuzz on the label about 6 malts and 4 hops is a bit too much. But it was lovely with a slice of spinach pizza.

22 oz bottle.  Pours amber, small head, blah, blah, blah.  Nothing exciting and just really one dimensional.  Aroma and flavor is malty and a small bitter finish.  Slightly watered down.  To sum it up with one word....boring.

Bottle Clear amber lager with a mid-sized, wispy, off-white head. Good retention. Toasty, biscuity, toffee and spicy hop aroma. Medium to full-bodied with intermediate carbonation. Like the nose, the flavor is biscuity and toasty with moderate, spicy, European hop bitterness. Lengthy, moderately bitter finish.

Amber-orange with a sudsy head. Light body, moderate carbonation, easy drinker. Malt profile had toast, rich toffee and a bit of caramel. Zingy, herbal bitterness (grassy, weedy). Decent beer, but nothing to raise a brow over.

22oz bomber-Poured a light amber body with a small white head which emits an aroma of malt and hops. Taste of the same with a little caramel thrown in. This light to medium bodied brew is very well balanced. It finishes with a bitter finish. Another good Coney Island.
I was happy with this beer.  You could definetly taste the hops and a little of the malt.  It had a small head with a little lacing.  The aroma was also nice.  I would have it again.
This amber ale poured with a fluffy beige head. It smells kind of like Coney Island. There is a thin malt flavor with a harsh bitter finish. This is not up to Hebrew’s standards.

small white cream (mostly dissapating) head into amber body with good lacing.  Aromas of mild malts and hops.  flavors of light to moderate bittersweet and finishes light bitter.  Some acidic apple in the finish, which is moderately long.  I was not a fan.
Dark amber, malty, caramel, little citrus, little dark fruits, little hops, slight nutty.

Bottle. Amber colored pour. Tall foamy off-white head. Nose is caramel, soft citrus, light earthy and floral hops, some spicy notes and toasted malt. Taste is caramel, sweet malts, fruit flavors (mostly citrus but a hint of pear in there), spicy and earthy hops, light floral notes and some nuttiness. The body on this is a bit chewy for a vienna with a moderate carbonation and a medium overall feel. Ends with more caramel, sweet malts, fruit notes, peanuts, spicy and floral hops and bready notes.

Bottle. Aroma of toasted malts, sweet notes, seguing in and out of fruitiness including cherry and lemon, maybe some semi-sour apple. Some supporting hops evident in the nose, but more so in the mouth, balancing nicely the otherwise sweet, rich malt, although the toasty character helps balance the sweetness as well. Fruity notes again dart in and out. A damn fine beer.

Bottle.  Pours a deep orange/brown with a thick, foamy light tan head.  Aroma of nice flowery hops with toasted and caramel malt.  Awesome!  Flavor is quite good as well, nice light floral hops and sweet malt.  Slight toasted malt presence, particularly in the finish.  Superbly drinkable.  Similar to SA Boston Lager but more full-bodied and not as sweet.  A top-notch vienna and one of the best lagers I’ve had.  Definitely superior to its 3.35 average.

06-Sep-08 (22-oz bottles: Purchased at BevMo in La Jolla, CA and www.liquidsolutions.net)  Terrible marketing if you ask me.  Coney Island Lager doesn’t inspire me to buy the beer because I’m thinking it might be a standard "Premium Lager," but as a beer geek, I bought it anyway (twice!), and it paid off because this beer is very lovely.  Big, malty flavors, fairly toasty, lightly sweet and caramely, even a touch smoky, with a gently bitter but not hidden hoppy character for a balanced finish.  Medium in body and carbonation, quite clean for a malt-driven beer, and easy to drink.  Malty, toasty, and mildly caramely nose, but it’s not more just than mildly sweet, and there’s a modest hop aroma in the background.  Amber in color with very nice clarity.  The off-white head rises to almost an inch on the pour before slowly settling to a wide ring.  Decorative, honeycomb-shaped lacing remains on the glass.  Much better than expected, a very nice Vienna-style lager, and definitely worth recommending.
Solid  lager. Dark golden color with a large white head. Lots of caramel going on with a nice bitter hoppy finish. Impressive.

Aroma is sweet with a little malt.  Color is a deep gold with a hint of orange.  Carbonation is good with a very thin head.  Taste is bright and hoppy.  Starting with medium body it goes down with a slight creamy feel.  Finish comes in sweet with a hint of malt then a bright hop flavor that has just a touch of citrus and a faint bitterness.  After taste is dry with the bitterness riding along.  This is a great Lager with amazing hop character.

Draft, Beer Island at the one and only Coney Island. Pours a transparent ruby color, moderate head. Lacy finish sticks to side of glass throughout the drink. Aroma is very faint and with sharp hop character. Taste is highly bitter with a hint of caramel. Palate is below average and goes down harsh with harsh aftertaste. Very dry. Expected more from this one but you might as well give it a shot if you are out on the boardwalk.
Pours amber into a stein. Off-white head quickly subsides to hug rim.  Crisp with caramel from front to back.  Dark caramel hop finish.
Clear reddish brown with almost no white head. Aroma is faint, but contains apple and spice.  Taste is burnt caramel with dry bitter elements. Carbonation is light but present. $5/22oz
Clear copper pour with a thick white and a small amount of spotty lace.  Caramel malts on the nose.  Medium bodied.  Sweet grainy flavor up front,  with slightly dry & bitter finish

Half inch, off-white head.  Clear body.  Moderate malt, light bread, light hoppiness, light yeast aroma.  Intial flavor was moderately sweet and a little bitter.  Texture was initially watery, but then dry on the tongue later.  Interting beer.  Could be a real good session beer.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white to light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is clear medium to dark amber.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (cookie, caramel), moderately hoppy (apricot, flowers, orange/grapefruit), with a light note of black tea.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation.

Reasonably nice, if simple, aroma followed by an uncomfortably sweet and syrupy mouth experience.  Sweetness lingers long after the swallow, and is only barely managed by bitterness. Ho hum overall.

Clear amber with a beige head.  Hoppy aroma, spices, caramel malts, and earthy.  Body lacks the intrigue of the aroma.  Some spice, malts, and little hop characteristics. Lightly carbonated.   Not a bad lager, but a little boring.

22oz bottle @Indiana Beerfest-pours an off white head and gold color.  Aroma is sweet medium malt-honey.  Taste is sweet medium malt-honey/caramel, off setting herbal/continental (Hallertau) hops.  Mild carbonation.

650 ml bottle from BOTW, Rochester (on sale!), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass.
App.:  An attractive shade of clear copper with a so-so off-white head.
  
Aroma:  Caramel, brown sugar, apples and other fruitiness, a little piney/grassy hops, a touch earthy and musty.
  
Palate:  Medium body and fairly full carbonation.

Havent had enough Viennas to judge adherence to style.  Doesnt do much for me as a beer
Straight forward Vienna. Basic and pretty good. Small bitter after taste, malt and mybe a bit of clove.
amber hue with off white fluffy head, the aroma is caramelly and sweet.  well carbonated, it has fruity body that has the flavor of can sugar and some malt.

Pretty, clear auburn with a thin, fizzy head.  Nose sweet with a bit of fruit, but pretty simple stuff, not much dancing up.  Flavor is quite sweet, a bit cloying.  Decent hop bite and the end, nice and crisp.  Somewhat bready in the malts, tries for a bit of depth but the sweetness kind of takes over.  Not a particularly impressive beer, but pretty good, certainly would be nice on a hot day, very drinkable stuff.  And it’s a Vienna, which there aren’t nearly enough of.

Translucent amber from a big scary bottle.  Nice head and color.  Light orange zest on the nose with a nice yeasty bread quality.  Flavor follows through with a nice hoppy bite but balanced with a nutty malt background.  Well done in it’s own right.

Thankfully I suffer from neither an irrational fear of clowns nor any qualms about being a wee bit of a freak myself. Take that, mix in some various lagers from Coney Island Brewing, and voila.

Currently only available in a 22oz bomber, my Coney Island Lager pours a deep orange amber hue, definitely a surprise from the light yellow lager I was expecting. A decent head of foam lingers, and then fades into a miniscule ring around my glass. In the nose I get some sweet malt and nutty character, with a crisp oily hop presence lingering in the background. Coney has had a few minutes to "warm" since I first poured her, and as I take my first quaff, an explosion of wet hop oils, bitter lemon rind and fresh cut grass. Backing it up are light sweet caramel and nutty notes. Despite its malty picture, hops are definitely taking precedence in the Coney Island Lager. As I delve deeper into my brew, the malty background of nuts and light caramel sweetness blends more smoothly with the domineering hop profile. A wet, medium body beer, the oils and hop esters seek solace under a soothing malty cover. This is definitely a beer that can benefit from a few minutes of "warming" to truly bring out all the flavor profiles in a palate pleasing balance.

Overall, an interesting interpretation of the lager style. While not overly intense in hops and malts, Coney Island Lager blends the two for a heavier palate. I would definitely enjoy another, but I wouldn’t consider her my favorite lager flavor.
Bomber. Clear orange/gold with an off white head. Sweet orange blossom nose, bready, light grain. Medium bodied, decent lace. Flavors fulfill the promises of the nose. Tasty and drinkable.

Bottle 650 ml
Appearance: Clear amber lager with creamy slightly darker top. Low visible carbonation. Little lacing shown. 3- Nose:  Sweet caramel malt with citric west hop twist. Slight straw grainy bottom with black tea feel. 6+ Flavor/Palate : Thinner front with tart fruity citric hops, slight woody English bitter like middle. Less body than average Vienna and with much higher alpha hop profile. More of American dark lager than Vienna.

22oz bottle, red cap.  Amber color, tan head.  Aroma of fresh malt combined with herbal hops.  Flavor has a spicy bite.  Sweet malt, honey, caramel.  Bitter hop flavors.  Creamy texture, woody finsih.  A very impressive lager.  Surprisingly enjoyable.

St. Petersburg, Fl. - Shep’s Deli - 22 oz bomber. Medium copper colored pour with a bubbly, airy white head. Not much of an aroma, a hint of fresh lake water and some graininess. Hint of bittersweetness in the flavor with some mild nutty flavors, a hint of caramel and a touch of bland lager. Nothing offensive here - just does not set my world on fire. Clean, even mouthfeel. Mark this one as average. Unlike other Coney Island brews this one does not sport a phallic symbol....unless I just do not "get" the smiling circus guy.

Poured from a 22 oz bottle at GOBF ’08...dark amber w/ a slight, fizzy off white head. Nose of citrus, floral hops, mixed with a cellar type funk. Great mix of flavors in this lager! A nice hop backbone blended well with some sweet malts, and caramel flavors. The palate was medium bodied, with the lager style carboantion (i.e. fizzy). Easily one of my favorite lagers!
Clear copper pour with fair eggshell head.  Sweet and malty.  Watery body.  Not too bad, but nothing all that special.  I do love the label though.

Pours clear amber with off white head that fades away quickly. Mild hoppy aroma and some caramel also. Flavor is slightly sweet with some maltiness. Not much going on. Light to meduim body with mild carbonation.

Bomber, no date. Pours copper/brown, hazy, looks a bit thick. Aroma is notable for some citrus. Taste is ale-ish, flavorful, if not completely clean. Caramel malt, grassy and citrus hop. Ultimately balanced. Not too far from an APA, though the body has lager fizz.
22 oz bottle.  Pours a amber color with a white head.  The aroma is malty with grassy hops.  Flavor is crisp and clean.  A good lager.
A hoppy beer, that I was very happy to try.  I was not disappointed at all and really enjoyed drinking it.  I would purchase again.
Sweet aroma of malt and light, grassy hops.  Amber with a large white head- decent lacing. Flavor is slight caramel, pine, hops. A very thin palate similar to killian’s. Overall ok.
Good beer, nicely even malts and hops for what’s its worth. slightly caramel with even piny hoppy flavor.
The aroma is malty with grassy hops. The appearance is amber with a large head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is thin but OK. Overall its good but its very simple.
Clear copper color pour with a medium head that fades quickly.  Aroma of light malt, grain and yeast.  Similar clean flavor.  Nice and crisp on the palate.  Refreshing.  A good lager.

Bottle from Beer Run in Charlottesville. Copper pour with a three finger head. Retention and lacing are both lacking. Crisap aroma with notes of grain, citrus, grass, pepper. Sweet grassy taste with a citrus hop bite. Medium body.

22 oz bomber. Pours to a beautiful, bright, copper color, with a tight white head that fades, and a moderate carbonation. The nose on this beer is nice with good herbal/grassy hop aromas, paired with some good pale malt aroma. The palate is crisp, and very clean, with good pale malt flavor, on a round body. This beer finishes with more good pale malt flavors, then ends with a slight grassy/herbal hop bite. Very balanced, very drinkable version of Czech pilsner. I would have enjoyed a little more hop aromas and bitterness in this one, but all and all a very well done beer, and stylistically pretty much on the mark. Good all around drinking beer, and a good beer to match with a nuimber of dishes.

translucent copper body with minimal white head...aorma of grassy hops, light earthy elements and little sugar..flavor is quite similar, and finishes slightly sweet..a touch of floral characteristics as well
A 22oz bottle. I got to say this has a lot more hops taste than expected. The body is dark gold with a white head. Taste and smell are floral and bitter. Nice hot summer day beer.
Dark gold into the glass with a nice white head.  Aroma is sweet grain and plenty of hop spice.  Flavor is much like a sam adams with fresher hop characteristics.

Draught at The Red in Santa Cruz.   Clear amber with a compact, creamy off-white head that leaves moderate lace.   Mostly hoppy aroma: floral, spicy, earthy, and a hint of citrus.   The flavor is a great balance of toffeeish malts and assertive, complex hop flavors.   The hops are a good blend of more citric american flavors, and more earthy and spicy european character. Just light enough to  politely pair with the portabella sandwich that I had, but with enough hop flavor to cut through the richness of the brie cheese on it.

Aroma is strong and malty with just a whisper of fruit - banana on second examination. Color is a dark honey-amber, not like your typical lager, and with a nice thick off-white head that sticks around for a bit. Flavor is smooth, malty with a fair amount of hoppy bitterness and a trace of fruit. Hop flavor dominates the aftertaste. This is rather different from what I expect when drinking a lager.

On tap at The Red in Santa Cruz. Poured into a pilsener glass. Light amber with lots of bubble columns. The aroma showcases an unusual hoppiness for a lager; sweeter citrus fruit comes through alongside the more classic earthy Saaz. The flavor has a nice maltiness that is part caramel and part cookie. The hops are mostly leafy and herbal but some of the citrus from the smell is detectable. Body is heftier than expected for the style, but this is still a very drinkable beer.
not good but it could be worse.  a litte off in the nose but fairly drinkable.  it came with free cotton candy at the bar, the biggest upside to the brew.
Bottle poured pale amber with a bit of a cream colored head. The nose and the flavor were pretty bland. Not a bad beer, but not too memorable.

This brew pours a clear amber body with a large fluffy head. Aromas of caramel and ripe malts, yet with the sweet citrus from the hops. Very floral but resembles breakfast at the local pancake house. a mouthfeel which is very pleasent overall and a little heavier than most Czech pilsners ive tasted.

From a 22 oz bottle this poured a deep copper color with a small off-white head and light lacing. Mild nose of caramel malts and floral hops.  Light mouthfeel. Flavor is malty with light hops.  Not much in the finish. Kind of bland, but drinkable.

light maroon copper color and a thin tan head. Light but fragrant aroma of candied malt and floral hops. A medium to light thick body and a crisp carbonation. Faint brown sugar and grain followed by a metallic hop note. Delicate, subtle, and balanced beer.

22 ounce bottle purchased at BevMo in Vacaville.  Aroma has some nice strawberry like fruitiness with some sugary and metallic malts.  This also has a significant floral quality to it. Clear copper color with small white head. Grassy floral hop nose. Flavor dominated by spicey hops with enough malt sweetness to back up. Finish is fairley sweet fading to some residual hop bitterness. Bit hoppy for a vienna style lager.

Poured an amber color with good head not much lacing.  Aroma was of pine hops and bread.  Flavor was much the same with caramel malts and lots of pine.  Was hoppyer then i expected.
Nice Golden clear color with white head.  Tastes of malts. very good and smooth.  I good beer.
Eh, not so bad. Pours a red/brown color, aroma is of thick malts, as is flavor, with a floral finish as it sits on your tongue. Thats it. Nothing really special.

22 oz. bottle, no freshness date, blurb and list of ingredients along the left side of the label (you can get the exact list of ingredients here, http://www.coneyislandlager.com), dry hopped with Cascade hops, sampled in a lager glass.

L: Slightly hazy appearance, amberish copper in color with an inch high head of beige fluffy foam that leaves behind a patchy amount of lace that follows the body down the glass as I consumed it.

S: Leafy, spicy, citric hops are the first smells I noticed, followed by toasted caramel and grains. Further whiffs bring out aromas of butter and honey bread. I like the aroma on this lager, it has that twist on the style that Ive come to expect from Shmaltz.

F&T: Smooth and softly crisp mouthfeel, touches of oily hop stickiness on the tongue, ending on a gulp inducing creamy note. This also possesses a good malty heftiness that makes this quite easy to consume. Obviously well thought out, well crafted blend of malts and hops, enough malty sweetness to combat the sour bitterness of the hops. Toasted malty tastes of caramel, grainy bread and toffee, towards the end flavors of honey butter and caramelized sugar add sweetness to the sour citric hops. The hops tastes hold their own and emerge slightly on top at the end. The peels of lemons and grapefruit, tea leafy, herbal earthy, finishing with a mild citric spicy bitterness. The finish also has a quick, clean dryness to it that makes the mouth water for more.

I really liked the Coney Island Lager from Shmaltz, uniquely different and highly enjoyable, I cant wait for the next one in the series.

Nice deep hazy golden coloured body with a thinnish white head. Aroma of strong malt - seemingly rye? with some good hops and nice yeast thrown in the mix. Medium-bodied; Strong rye flavoured malty taste with some mild hops and a bit of nuts. Aftertaste shows more rye, alcohol, hops and a good alcohol overtone. Overall, a good spring/summery beer with the malt sticking out most. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from K&E Discount Beverage in New Paltz, New York on 19-April-2008.

Taste is perhaps a bit hoppy for a lager, malty, medium bodied and a full flavored nice lager.  Perhaps a touch lemony as well.  Not offensive, is easy drinking, and pretty solid for what it is.

Very clear copper amber body with a medium frothy off-white head. Sweet hoppy aroma with some caramel and sugar. Clean caramel and sugar flavor, some light hop flavor and a good bitter finish. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

Pours clear gold with a medium white head.  Lager aroma of yeast, sugar, some hops.  Watery, corny taste at first, but comes back later with more hops.  A sugary cereal taste is prevalent throughout.  Not great, but not bad.

+did not like. Would not buy+

Aroma: very faint. Clean. Floral. App: eh. Normal. Flavor: like a kinda bad IPA. Do not care for the flavor. It is not gross though. Palate:fine. OA: normal IPA flavor. Not good. Not bad

1 Pt-6floz bottle.  Golden haze pour small head but great carbs.  Nice mix of malts and hops, not over hoped as I thought it would be.  I enjoyed this Lager, smooth and mild on the pallet plus the Czech yeast I believe brings it all together.  Very drinkable would have it again.
22oz bottle, malty aroma, golden pour. watery mouth feel. flavors  bitter hops, sour finish. I did not care for this beer much.

Golden/orange pour...nice attractive and lingering head.  The nose is fairly hoppy...citrus and pine, but also some caramel malt.  The flavors are likewise hop forward...but balanced pretty damn well by the big caramel/toffee base.   Very interesting version of a Vienna.

22 oz bottle from North Park Liquor. Poured as a tea brown color with minimum amount of foam. The flavor and aroma are both boring and bland with only a taste of malt and watered down hops. Not good so I give this a thumbs down.

Nice ruby tan color, minor but long-lasting head. Aroma of honey, oats, light lemon - kind of spritzy. Understated but surprisingly complex. Nicely balanced sweetness level in flavor, delicious doughy malts, light roastiness. Very well balanced bitterness. This beer is extremely put together and quaffable, yet there is plenty of complexity there to entertain the palate should one be interested.

Bottle. Poured a small, fizzy off-whte head that mostly diminished, transparent, carbonation observed, fair amount of lacing, and a dark straw hue. Nose was hoppy, citrus, malty, and citrus. Ditto for the flavor along with some pine taste. Tingly mouthfeel and medium in body. I was pleasantly surprised that this was tastier than what I was anticipating for some unknown reason. Hoppier than I thought it would be and in a good way. Very quaffable and worthy of a try IMO. I would drink this again as it is a nice, easy drink.

Bottle. Pours copper with thin, off-white head. Nose has sharp floral, slightly metallic hops, some butterscotch. Aroma is mild overall. Flavor is soft bread, very lightly sweet, mild buttery notes. Prominent bitter citrus-like hop background. Citrus and slightly floral resiny bitterness and a very mild tartness linger on the palate. Fluffy, soft mouthfeel. Hoppy but not really enough malt depth.

Bottle from State Line.  Poured dark straw going toward copper, with off-white head.  Aroma was grainy, cereally malt, some hopcitrus.  The taste was crisp and clean, not offering anything out of the ordinary, but not offering anything offensive either.

The 22 oz. bomber was adorned with a label befitting a funhouse theme I associate with Coney Island (although I have never been there personally).  The Beer came out orange amber in color with some chill haze.   Carbonation was fine and gentle, which made me wonder if this was bottle conditioned.  The aroma was very toasty and caramelized and was layered with a follow up smell of spicy noble hops.  The taste was well balanced between the simple bready sweetness of caramel malts and surprisingly bitter hops.  Not watery like most Vienna lagers, this was a flavorful and caressing treat.  Went fabulously with a plate of Indian cashews and Marcona almonds.

Bomber shared with Degarth courtesy of Degarth. Thanks again. The pour comes out deep copper with thin off white head. The aroma is mild with faint grainy to pale maltiness followed by some spice hops. The taste is full and refreshing with a solid pulse of pale malts to grainy malts to mild caramel and biscuit malts. Hops are noticed too with floral flowery notes and spice. Nice session beer with solid flavors.

Bottle shared by bfeld. The pour was an orangey amber, somewhat flat color, thin light peachy color. The aroma was grainy, bready, piney hops. The flavor followed suit, bready, caramel malts with grassy and piney hops, finishing pretty hoppy for an amber lager (certainly outside the vienna style itself), pretty enjoyable, although the hopping and maltiness tended to overwhelm any lager crispness in this thing. A nice brew.

Bottle sampled. Pours amber in color with a small off-white head. Aroma of caramel, grain, floral, and citrus hops. Flavor is caramel, toasted malts, floral hops, and a hint of toffee with a nice crisp bite and a bitter finish.

Deep orange/amber pour with white head. Aroma of peat and light malt. Nice maltiness and light hints of hops. Slightly thin but excellent carbonation. Over all a pretty solid drinker. I gave it one point for the label. I will say that were this beer available here I would drink it often. I dont know who brought it but thanks.

A very nice beer, well put together. Sweet caramel aroma with grassy hops. Golden amber pour, 1/2" thick head and good lacing. Full bodied and creamy with a mild sweetness and lightly bitter finish. Nutty taste, mildly toasted and caramel malt. Well hopped providing a fresh grassy flavor. Well balanced beer.
Fruity and grainy aroma. Clear orange color with a large white head and good lacing. Slightly sweet start that gets a musty malt finish. Good palate.

I walk into Bierkraft in Brooklyn and Tim is there stocking. He sees me coming in and grabs a bottle and then hands it over to me...no words spoken. I think to myself: "Hrmph. Thats interesting." (its never happened before, and I am in there quite a bit) 

Pours a clear amber. Big cream head. Nice color. Fragrance is a slight caramel tone with some wood on there as well. Nothing significant going on here, but I feel like what little is there is earthy. Flavor is slightly hoppy, but then a smooth malty smoothness kicks in. Interesting. Complex. Slight woody sweetness. Feel is good. Not a whole lot of body on the liquid, but a nice bubble on there. Overall extremely drinkable. Definitely a session brew. Definitely worth trying. Save Coney Island! (drink more beer)
22 oz bottle pours a nice clear golden-amber.  Herbal - Lemony hop aroma.  Flavor is malty, grainy, very lightly hopped.  Very easy to drink.

Bright amber appearance with a small, off white head.  Malty, mildly spiced aroma.   Caramel malts add a touch of sweetness to the taste.  Grainy, herbal flavors further enhance the palate.  Smooth, medium bodied mouthfeel with average carbonation.  Clean, dry finish does not linger.  Nicely put together.

Pours with an almost three finger thick, light tan colored head.  The beer is brilliantly clear, but is a nice red color, which I wasnt expecting, when held up to the light the beer shows a red-hued, copper color.  The aroma is a nice mix of fruity hops and sweet malt.  The hop character, while somewhat soft, has a real nice mix of spice and herbal notes to it; touches of cinnamon, hints of sweet basil and perhaps a touch of lemon grass.  Soft, sweet malt character that is lightly caramelized and has a touch of berry-like fruitiness to it (though this is most assuredly contributed by the hops as well) is found up front, while the finish has notes of crushed soda crackers and dusty malt to it.  The aroma, while somewhat subtle overall, is really quite nice; I really am enjoying the interplay between hop and malt and how much each of them bring to the aroma.

Lightly sweet as it hits the tongue for the first time, the beer quickly picks up a nice herbal hoppiness as well as a soft, nip of bitterness.  Underlying caramelized grain notes and sweet grain contribute a slight body to this brew that provides a palate coating fullness that I was not necessarily expecting of this brew (meaning it drinks a little bigger than its 5.5% might suggest).  This has a ton of malt and hop character; herbal, almost mint-like, fruity with berry notes, touches of bergamot, slightly astringent / green hops in the finish, biscuit notes, crushed soda crackers, chewy bread crust and perhaps a touch of grape-like or honey like malt character.

Quite clean tasting (as a good lager should be), but it has a nice full flavor of malt and hop character.  Really the only thing keeping this from being incredibly good is that the hop character gets a touch too astringent and green in the finish.  This is definitely a really pleasant surprise, I wasnt expecting much when I cracked the top of this brew.  I have no idea what "style" this beer is, the interesting use of American hops here puts this in a category of its own, but it is quite tasty and certainly worth tracking down for the lower-alcohol lager lovers out there.

Bottle. Copper/amber beer with a tan head. Malty, light spice aroma. Clean malt flavor with a bit of grass and spice. Medium-light body. Easy drinking. LIngering light malt, light mineral, light spice.

A beer doesnt have to be big and heavy to be well crafted and this one is done nicely.
Clear deep copper with a small off-white head.
Juicy caramel malt aroma.
Lots of Munich malt flavors here with some nice hop dry notes coming in towards the finish.

Pours a transparent copper orange with a spotty-lacing off-white head.  Aroma of lightly toasted and sweet caramel malts with a touch of lager yeast.  Body starts fairly full and semi-sweet with a bready maltiness and a drier toasty finish.  A pretty good Vienna.

Appearance: Pours a nice, orangey-copper body with a full, frothy off-white head. Tiny-bubbled effervescence.

Smell: Mild, toasty caramel maltiness with a touch of graininess. Bright Saaz noble hop bouquet with further notes of grass, citrus, and floral to enjoy as well.

Taste: Light caramel and pale maltiness with a slight toastiness and sweetness. Lemony, grassy, even herbal hop flavors with a medium bitterness is fast on the malts heels, though. Hint of orange. Floral, fruity finish with a lingering bitterness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: That being said, I defy any person with a soul to not enjoy this Vienna.

Bottle at stevos. Pours light copper with decent ivory head. The aroma is grainy with some melon and spicy wheat notes. The flavor has grainy sweetness, tree bark, and melon. Dry-ish spicy finish. Not bad... kind of a pleasant surprise, I must say.

22 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquor - Pours a slightly hazy copper color with a 3/4 finger thick off white head.  Faint spotty lacing.  Has a very light toasted malt aroma.  Flavor is light malt and herbal hops.  Light to medium body.  Easy drinking with no lingering aftertaste.  A good beer.

That label...Man, thats just good old fashioned nightmare fuel right there. Copper, with a decent sized head. Grainy, rye-ish aroma. Some malty notes at first, then a few smokey, peaty notes. very clean tasting. Would be a pretty good summer beer. Thanks to Springslicker for sharing this one at Stevofest!

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2008 Sampled at Stevofest 08, courtesy of Springslicker. Label looks like a cover of a Dangerous Toys album! Pours a deep copper with a diminishing white head. Aroma of german malts and a hint of maple. Medium bodied with a nice comfortable carbonation. Malt profile really dominates here, which has notes of munich malts- bread and dark caramel. There is a soft herbal bitterness mid-palate. Clean finish. This was sort of blend of a Helles and Vienna. Could use a little more spicy bitterness for me if Vienna was the intent. However, a very clean beer that would be great for a summer cookout

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2008 Bottle from BevMo. Pours a medium amber color. Slightly sweet aroma. Some caramelized maltiness. A hint of hops. Crisp maltiness up front with a bit of a citric hop touch. Finish is grapefruit hoppiness. A Lot hoppier than most Ive had of this style.

Hazy amber color.  Decent head.  Typical for the style hop aroma.  Nice flavor.  Sort of a tartness to it with some great lager hop twang.  This is much better than I would have guessed from looking at the label.  Glad the wife picked it up.  Enjoyable.
22 oz bomber from Windmill Farms.   Nice amber color, aroma is spicy hops.  Light, clean, crisp, refreshing.   Everything a good lager should be.   Awesome Vienna.

Pours with a lightly hazed, coppery/golden body, affluent effervescence and a long-holding off-white head. Aroma is sweet and diverse with notes of citrus, green, grassy herbals, a bready undertow and a malted drizzle of caramel. Slightly cloying, but the balance between malt and hop is well-executed. Flavors are rather intense but none truly shows dominance. Caramel, chocolate, orange,  grasses... sweetness at first, then lingering with a low hop bite. I found a slight, boozy, Southern Comfort note in the finish which I didnt care for, but overall this was intricate and satisfying. 
<font size=-4>22 oz. bomber from a friend at Christmas.</font>

22 oz. glass bottle- color of, amber, with a medium tan colored head - nose of mild malts, some soapiness , and subtle hops   taste of pale hops, ever so slight malts, and very mild soap - body is dry , and light , and with medium high carbonation  aftertaste of mild hop, bitter, and dry
Bottle.  Pours a nice clear amber with a bubbly white head.  The aroma is Saaz hops.   Taste is a "European" hoppiness.  Very lagerish and dry.

Amber pour with a nice looking creamy tan head that lasts.  Herbal aroma with a bit of bisquit and dough.  Very flavorful for such a light brew.  Toasted malt, caramel, more bread/bisquit and a very light floral hop character.  There is a nice pils quality towards the finish, which is bitter and long.  Its a bit thin but definitely a good session beer and it goes down easy!

Bomber from Country Club Liquors; Nose of grain, caramel, and flowery hops; copper with a medium beige head; flavor has caramel, light hop bitterness, and a little light fruitiness; finish a tiny smidgeon of hops.

Big ol bottle.  Pours light amber wtih a big pock-marked head.  The nose is quite aromatic ... almost Saazy, almost Northwesty.  It drinks with a mellow smoothness not uncommon to a "Vienna" but this has more built-in character than that, hinting at the more Americanized stylistic twists of hoppiness, hinting at a floral brew.  Intersting brew.  Bring on the hot dogs.  (#3264, 1/1/2008)
Clear light amber pour.  Apperance is just about the only thing that gives away the lager classification.  It has a nice chew body.  Very floral type hoppiness with a bitter finish more like an apa.

Clear amber/light copper body, thin-medium off-white to buff head. Bready, caramely nose, with herbal hops. Thin body, tightly carbonated, with light toffee and sweet breads, earthy, herbal hops, with a peppery, bitter finish. Thin. Basic.
Overall is so high because of the drinkability.  Crisp refreshing lager that was enjoyable to just kick back and enjoy.  A great lawnmower beer.

pours a clear orange/amber with a large off-white head.  toasted malt and hop aroma.  awesome flavor with tons of bready, toasty malts and fresh green floral hops while keeping a light body.  a fantastic vienna.

Bomber. Light amber body with a light off white head. The aroma is light orange soda with some roasted peanuts. There is also some Juicy Fruit gum. The taste is light bread crust with some orange peel notes. A very light body that is slick and thin. Soft carbonation. This is unlike any other Vienna I have tried, more like a Premium lager or maybe even a watered down American Dark Lager. Decent stuff that I would not mind having as a session beer.

Pours a clear, lighter amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of some toasted malts, floral and citrus hops, and some caramel malts.  Flavor is rather lighter then expected with the toasted malts dominating.  Finishes with a little bitterness from the floral hops.  Decent beer but nothing amazing.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2007 A Vienna? I dont think so. More like a soapy, cheap lager. Aromas are of soap, as well as the flavors. Nothing special here. Wish I could get a refund on all the money Ive spent on bad beer.
Maybe I got a bad bottle?

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2008 Bottle from BevMo.  Poured a nice copper color with a creamy head.  Nose was malty with some hop essence.  Reminded me of Sam Adams Boston Lager but with more flavor and easier to drink.
I really liked this, consider its a larger (vienna) and its outstanding.  I think thats why its so highly rated. Full of flavor, aroma, and character.
bottle.  copper pour with thin head.  fragrant aroma of hops, lemon grass, grainy malts.  rich and malty.  nice hoppiness.  sweet.  great lager.
