6/3/6/3/13 - 3.1 ( 12/5/2007)

pours a clear deep copper with a small white head, and some lacing.

smell is of toasted nuts, grain, some grass, malt, a little citrus, and a little sweet caramel.

taste is of malt, popcorn, grain, some hops, dry grass, touch of citrus, and a touch of caramel, ends a somewhat dry and a little bitter.
Amber pour, small to moderate head, decent lacing and retention. Aroma is toast, caramel, butter, grass, lighter fruits. Medium to light body, moderate to low bitterness, low sweetness. Solid.

Bomber poured a clear copper with a small lasting amber head. Aromas of carmel, citrus and bread. Palate was light to medium bodied and crisp. Flavors of bread, carmel and citrus with a crisp lingering bitter finish.
22oz bottle.  A little more complex than I had assumed.  Deep bronze amber color. Rich and malty, with the sweetness pleasantly balanced by the subtle dryness and complexity of the hops.

Light caramel aroma with a hint of hop. Slightly hazy amber color with a decent white head. Near full body with creamy, brisk carbonation. Caramel flavor with some pretty decent hop - noble, citrus - floral? Seems a bunch. Definitely citrus. The finish is reasonably dry, and the bitter tends to build. This is 50% of the way to Boston Beers Imperial Lager. Very nice in the mouth. Best lager Ive had today, this week, this month, ... It is really good - an ale drinker should be able to enjoy this.

Bottle; poured a rich orange, amber with a slightly off white head.  Aroma of caramel, yeast and citrus.  Very clean tasting and a pretty good example of the style.  However, I was expecting just a bit more based on the rather high ratings.  Very malty, with a slight hoppy ending (grassy).  Malt was caramel and toasted.  Possibly a good gateway beer for the standard lager drinker.

Pours amber w/ a decent head. Good head retention reducing to a full canopy and fluffy ring. Bright cheery citrus rind on the nose. Makes me want to smile real big like the clown on the lable. Medium nectar w/ ample residual effers. Big and malty w/ a fast setting hop component to balance this beast. I can taste a bit of berry fruit in here but its so mild and Robo Hop is adimant about keeping his post fruit free. I detect a slight biscuit and herb essence also. The finish is bittered well.
(draft) Clear amber body with off-white head, nice lacing.  Aroma is medium sweet, orange/floral, light bread.  Taste is medium sweet, floral, some herbal, bread/cereal.  Medium body, some chewiness.

Bottle and served in standard pint glass: Amber hued with a fading fizzy head and spotty lace. The aroma has notes of grassy and herbal hops, caramel and grainy malt, a dusty yeast and a slight peppery ester. The taste has a nice kick of herbal bitterness over a layer of biscuity malts. There is a hop spice finish and a hint of metallic character. The mouth feel is crisp around the edges with a grainy aftertaste. Not bad, quaffable brew.

this is one of the better lagers ive ever had. it smells great and has more flavor than just about any other   lager ive had. 

on tap at City Beer San Francisco
Very drinkable.  Nice amber pour.  Nice grassy hop aroma with hops and sweet malt on the tongue.
Psycho bottle reveals a standard, but drinkable brew.  For a lager, it did have a bit of a bite.

Very nice looking color as it sits a beautiful light shade of bronzed gold with a slight chill haze to its body. Small lavish capping of foam sits briefly before sliding to a beefy skimming and lots of tiny speckled lacing spewn across the glass. 

Aroma is dulled pale malt, muddled sweetness of potato and bread dough. Partial low tones of grassy toasted hops and a flinting of spice to its pale nature. 

Flavors are simple, natural, and wholesome; kinda crisp and toasty in the front, bit of sweet in the middle, quite low ended and even going as it makes a subtle turn into the finish with a touch of grassy Saaz-like hop spice. A late kick of stale pretzeled dough remains as if fades off quickly. 

Body is light/medium, crisp, yet dullish in tone for flavors and subtle snappy carbonation that gives a smooth ring to the palate as its easily smackable and a tiny bit more tasty then you realize. 

Its no knock out of the park, but it has a well-crafted nature that suits it well and is comfortable for drinking.
Pours clear, brown, witha moderate head. Aroma is hoppy with a solid malty backing. Full mouth feel with a lightly fruity quality. Strong hop quality, but really balanced with the malts.
Very nice, rich lager. Bit of hops to it. Nice deep taste, unlike other lagers which feel too light.  Well done.

Bottle: Orange hued caramel, ever so slight haze, large frothy off-white head, clumpy lacing. &nbsp Musty basement like malt aroma, smidgen of hops, even minor grainess. &nbsp Moderate malt base, not as much as I would have thought. &nbsp A bit more hop presense than expected. &nbsp Clean, with a little cardboardish malt on the finish. &nbsp Doesnt detract tho. &nbsp Hint of sweetness throughout. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Could stand to have a bit more thickness. &nbsp That would seal the deal for me. &nbsp Otherwise more enjoyable than expected. &nbsp So far one of the better Shmaltz beers I have had. &nbsp Not up to par with Eliot Ness, but still enjoyable. &nbsp Would be perfect if it were a little thicker, and slightly sweeter.
Cereal grains in the flavor, some caramel, and toast flavors (very subtle).  With a good hop flavor that provides a good crisp bite.  Nice lager.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear amber body with a medium-sized creamy off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, citrus, grass, and florals.  Flavor of caramel, mild grassy hops, nuts, and toasted malt.

bomber. solid bronze color gives me hope for this lager. a word that can often be scary. pours with a half inch of solid white head. clean and mild grains appear with some grassy hops as well. clean and very smooth with an impressively full palate.  the flavor is less intense than the nose had lead me to believe. still it does taste great. enough rich malt and hop bite to make this a pleasure to drink.

This has a pour that makes one want to drink the beer, a rich amber/orange body highlighted in gols with a tall, dense ecru head.  Great lacing.  The aroma is caramel and a bit of toffee topped with sturdy hop scents of tart citrus fruits, flowers, and a bit of earthiness.  This is well carbonated and spicy warm on the tongue.  Its got rich malty flavors balanced with the aforementioned hops, the latter leading to a crisp, dry, and lightly bitter finish.  Interesting interpretation of a Vienna... and quite tasty.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Pak Liquors, Indianapolis, IN<font size=-1>

this aint no lager i evah had. but, it is good beer.  substantive (the good way) and a nice mouthfeel. good malt base with a touch of sweetness. hop character better than several ipas i have had. nice lingering finish. this beer is a quality but somewhat simple ipa. it is dark orange and i highly reccommend it!
On tap. Slightly auburn pour. Mostly dry, refreshing, with a touch of german malt sweetness. A little spice. Goes down easy. Nice beer, good to see some decent lagers around.
Golden color.  Smell of malt, hops, sugar, bread, citrus and some spice.  Taste of hops, malt, citrus, spice, caramel, bread and some grass.  Refreshing brew.

22oz Bomber
A light golden yellow color with a thick head.  This was a pleasant lager to drink had some good charatcers and great flavors.  Liked the beers underlying spicy flavor and finished quite nice.

Aroma has a hint of butterscotch and hops, but not much else.  Somewhat dark lager with a good head.  A lot of citrus hop taste, but its a good match to the malt level.  Decent mouthfeel, but lacks a good finish.

Bottle from Rivers Bend. Poured clear amber color with a large frothy white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate sour citrus aroma. Medium body with soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Drinkable smooth brew.

Pours hazy amber, nice apperance.  Aroma is pretty hoppy and has some caramel in there as well.  Definately hoppy with a fairly good balance of sweet malts.  The finish is kind of gritty and not to my liking.  Not a bad lager though.

Cant believe my little local Grocer stocks this.  Lager purest might not approve, cause it tastes like an IPA to me.  Very hoppy.  burnt toast and caramel corn.  Supersize frothy blond head.  Best lager.

22oz bottle - Pours light amber with a substantial white head.  It has an aroma of sweet malt and some light, citrus hops.  The flavor is hoppier than I expected with crisp, moderately strong bitterness balanced fairly well by the caramel malts.  Its a medium bodied beer that finishes with some good bitterness.  Its available at World Market around here.

I love the packaging. Extra points for kick ass graphics! Pours amber with copper highlights. Quickly disappearing white head. Aroma of grain, lightly roasted malt, grass with a hint of sweetness. Fairly crisp on the palate with a good amount of crisp malt and grassy hops to finish it off. Medium bodied. Very crisp and refreshing. Nice!

Coppery red with a small tan head.  Aroma of dry grains, sweet malt and a hint of bitterness.  Flavor of grain and sweet malt  with an herbal bitterness in the finish.  Nice mouthfeel and not too strong on the carbonation.  Not bad at all.

Mild sweet grain malt aroma with wisps of hops, taste was a rather full bodied sweet grain flavor ,almost sugary at times with a noticeable hop bitterness in finish, lacked the crispness of a lager, displayed the full bodiness you would expect from all those different malts and hops,reminded me of an American version of an Oktoberfest, very interesting,thanks Kingpin

Bomber consumed at the Freak Bar at Coney Island.  Pours copper with a tan head.  Smells of sweet malt and some corn with some peppery splashes.  Tastes very refreshing with some tea like elements and earthy hints.  A fun beer at a fun and unusual place.  Consumed with some of the freaks from the 10 in 1 freak show.

I have no idea how this 22 oz bottle made its way to a small grocery store in Salem,Oregon.
Lovely looking lager, dark copper with a large tan head. Great laceing throught the galss.
Aroma I wasnt so pleased with, its sort of malty/nutty but with some off putting "cheesy sock" thing going on.
Nice taste to strong on the malts, dark and semi-bitter, with a great zing of grassy/sherberty hops near the  end. Pleasant hop aftertaste.
Nice mouthfeel to this one, smooth under the well done carbonation.
Drinkable vienna, very nice.

Pours clear bronze with a bubbly light tan head.  The aroma has well toasted smooth malt, some nuttiness and a bit of hops.  Medium crisp body with quite a bit of sharp carbonation.  The taste starts with dark toasted nutty malt and dry caramel.  The finish adds some earthy / spicy hops   A very respectable lager.

Brown and clear with an off tan, frothy head.  Good lacing for the duration.  Malty sweet aroma.  This beer was better than I thought it would be.  Clean and sweet and asking for salty foods.  More hop prescense than I expected.  It added a crispness that was very nice.

Pours a clear dark brown, slightly orange-ish with a small head.  Aroma is present with macro-corn, caramel sweetness and some West Coast citrus hops.  Taste is smooth with light lagered sweetness and again some felt hoppiness but more flroal and earthy.  Finishes with low bitterness and a lagered fruitiness.  Lighted bodied with average carbonation.  Gets some bonus points for reppin my old hood, the big C.I. in BROOKLYN!!!!!!! Im telling you this will be a collectors item one day. 22oz bomber, Rodenbach Grand Cru smaller tulip glass.

text: Pour is a dark brown with a large soapy white head.   Aroma is nice crisp hop with a huge helping of caramel malts.  Flavor is about the same.  Some pine hops with a very caramel malt backbone.  Deffinatly not a typical lager but worth having around the house for a lazy afternoon.

In the bomber bottle from Beertopia. Pours amber with a medium-sized thick fluffy ivory colored head. I think that this beer might make me realize what the term "Session Beer" really means! It has a mild aroma of flowery nectar water and subdued hops. This is smooth and easy to drink. The mild hop bitterness at the finish is mildly pine-like. Has a great palate and is perfectly hopped for such a medium bodied lager. The brilliance to this beer is that it does not over or under state anything. Yummy and worth drinking often.

Bomber.  Poured clear healthy caramel with lots of rising carbonation and a short cap of beige head.  The aroma was quite enjoyable with wet grass and bready sweetness accented by ample doses of floral and citrusy hoppage.. very Czech-lagery as one might say.  Flavor was even better.. crisp bread and fruity notes at the core with bright citrus and floral bitterness leaving an exclamation on the finish.  Crisp and clean on the palate with a smooth flow.  Didnt see this one coming!

Highly filtered, with a big-bubbled, off-white head over a copper-colored body.  Dark for a lager.  Ill start with my favorite part of this beer: the finish.  It is very smooth and fruity.  Crisp and clean.  The flavor is mild but good.  Very malty.   It really does taste pretty much like a Czech-style lager.  Good.

Clear copper beer, with a pillowy white head that is well-sustained by the bubbly body - spicy european hop aroma, with notes of butter and bread - the flavor is fairly robust - crisp hop bite up front, followed by some biscuit and gingerbread, then some butter and caramel come into play - some light peppery hints and a long-lingering hop profile - it gets a bit sweet near the end, but the hops do a nice job of keeping it in check - this seems more like a Vienna than anything else, and a fairly tasty one at that.

22oz bomber.  Filtered with an evolving amber to golden hue.  Finger width of creamy off-white head.  Sweet citrusy cereal aromas.  Touch doughy.  Medium bodied with a nice crisp palate.  Dry and effervescent.  Good malt character.  Cookie and caramel.  Nice bitterness.  Nice and big for the style.  Great swirl around the mouth.  Only down side is the soapy lingering flavor.  The finish is big and bright.  Spicy peppery piney citrusy hops.  Ill be having more of these!

Bottle @ the Coney Island Freak Show. Amber with a dense creamy head. Has a nice chewy body and a sweet caramel malt aroma, along with spicy hops. Has a European Strong Lager feel to it. Lots of bready, caramel malts to give it body. Along with peppery zesty hops (Hallertau) that balance it nicely. A well made lager.

Pours deep amber with a tall cream colored head. Hoppy lager, with a rich caramel and ceral flavor, crisp and spicy hops, and trailing bitter finish. I liked it, although a touch more sweetness would improve it for me, a bit sharp in the bitterness hides the nice malt flavors.
Bottle.  Pours an ambery, hoppy looking brown and tastes it too. Some cinnamon and bitterness with a bit of sweetness to finish. Pretty decent, would make a good session beer I think.

Attractive clear orange amber body with a sturdy almond head. Aroma of caramel, spicy hops and some fruity esters. Nicely balanced with spicy and earthy hop bitterness and toasty caramel maltiness. A hint of red apples underneath. Nice drinking lager.
Poured a bronze-copper colored body with a chunky and frothy beige-white head. Nose of grains and floral hops. An all-around nice afternoon beer!

Only available in Minnesota and New York from what Ive been told. Note to self: Dont open a bomber right after you remove it from the refrigerator if its been laying on its side. Beer goes all over. Profits from this brew go to help Coney Island.

Pours a nice clear golden copper caramel color with a nice white head sitting on top. The foam slowly settles and leave no real lacing. Looks like a good lager should. Sweet malty aroma up front and then a bit of fruit and a strange touch of hops you dont expect from a lager. Fruit mixed with caramel fill the nose with a slight bit of bitterness in the distance. Very nice but not expected. Smooth caramel malt body flows over the tongue. Nice and crisp on the end. The aftertaste brings with it a nice fruity hop flavor. Bit of bitterness at the end of the aftertaste. Nice lager and easy to drink. Pretty cool stuff.

Nose of spice, grass, & perfume.  Pours a clear copper.  The nice cascade resolves into a fully lasting off-white rocky head that leaves behind good lace.  The brew is spicy with a good malt profile well balanced by a more than adequate hops presence.  The rewarding finish is long.  The medium creamy body is lively and feels clean at the finish.  I have a bone to pick with whoever entered this brew as a "Pale Lager".  IMHO this is a perfect example of a "Premium Lager".

Pours a rich golden with no head.  Super biscuity malt with some honey and a light floral touch on the nose.  Flavor is kinda muddled and confusing, but lends a sweet almost cotton candy, or honeysuckle type sweetness, with a nice floral hop finish.

text: Bronze colored liquid with a wispy bigger bubbled off-white head. Touches of malt and light caramel in the minimal aroma. Hint of floral hops, but there again just a hint. Light caramel flavor with a touch of sweet herbal hops and lightly toasted malt. Certainly drinkable. Some light sour dough bread buttered with a sweet cream butter hides in the finish. Once again there is nothing in your face about this beer, except the label. Another light amber lager for the masses.

Draught at ReBar.  Darkish gold to amber color with a light cereal malt aroma spiked with some fresh grass and lemon hops.  Toasty, slightly sweet cereal malt flavor with balancing citrusy hops.  Some pleasant fruity (appley) notes throughout as well...a nice surprise for a lager.  Basically decent for a "kitsch" beer, though I know the bottles are way overpriced.

Here we have a clear case of a purchase made for the label art. Love that cool circus freak. A Schmltz fan, but never a lager lover, I bought it to look at that awesome design. So be it.

Clear amber color. Nice bubbles above.

Slightly sweet nose, minor hops, but there. Largely quiet.

Taste: smooth, clean, and watery. Just like a good lager should be. Hops dance happily on the tongue, before disappearing. Eight malts make for smoothness and creamy-tivity, with a lasting tingle on the palate. 
Quite tasty.
Hail freaks, geeks, barkers, and carnies!

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2007 Amber-gold with a light malty nose.  Light earthiness with a touch of caramel and faint grassiness as well.  Flavour is decently malty with light earthy hops.   Moderately sweet up front, light graininess throught the middle with a touch of grassy hops on the back.  I didnt enjoy it all that much the first few times, but its grown on me lately... oh, yeah, and the label is beyond creepy.
On tap at Mugs. Amber in color with a nice white head. Light hoppy malty aroma. Grainy notes. Hoppy flavor. Caramel notes. Light malty character. Thin. Light tasting. Clean finish. Ok beer.
Very good for the style.  Light hop aroma.  Flavor has malt and enough hops that I might call this an English pale ale, almost.  Creepy label.
Amber Color with Off White Head.  Malt and Floral Hops Aroma.  Nice Caramel Flavor Mixed with Subtle Hop Taste.  Tasted Closer to an Amber. Alot of Nice Session Flavor for a Lager.
From tap at blind tiger in nyc. Lovely clear amber served in lager glass.  Aroma: fragrant floral hops and sweet malt. Finish: clean, bright, soft aftertaste.

Beer from 22-oz bottle sampled at Cellars Wine & Spirits Friday tasting, pours a clear copper amber brew with an average off-white head. Dissolves to a fine film and foam ring. Aroma of multi-grain, some cotton candy, and floral hops. Taste is lightly carbonated with a light fruit character. Finish is a clean and crisp with a slight watery aftertaste.
Dark gold color with no head.  Aroma of cotton candy and corn.  More of the same in the flavor along with a very musty hop taste.  Slightly sour finish.
Cotton candy nose on this amber beer.  Faint corn in the body with cotton candy flavor as well.  Some corn floating around as well.  The cotton candy surprisingly was pulled off rather well.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2007 This pale laeger pours with a deep amber almost red hue color.  It has nice notes of sweet malt and floral hops that show cotton candy!  The mouthfeel turns the classic bitter flavors into a lightly sweet fruit flavor.  The fiinish is crisp with the correct amount of bitterness.  I found about this beer from my friends at Bierkraft in Brooklyn.
